MOSCOW Russia is ready to do its part to fully restore ties with Washington following the election of businessman Donald Trump as the next U.S. President

column4: uncertain path.Among those uncertainties will be the Trump administration's future relations with Russia. Ties between Washington and Moscow have become increasingly strained over the conflicts in Ukraine and Syria
column5: and allegations of Russian cyber attacks featured in the U.S. election campaign.

column3: but we are ready to do our part and do everything to return Russian and American relations to a stable path of development
column4: he added.

column1: This would be good for both the Russian and American people and have a positive impact on the climate of world affairs.""Trump is widely viewed as friendly to the Kremlin and Putin has said previously his future counterpart is a talented and colorful character.

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-marijuana-idUSKBN1331B9	California voters embrace recreational marijuana	"
By Sharon Bernstein and Steve Gorman
| SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif./LOS ANGELES

column1: SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif./LOS ANGELES A ballot measure to make recreational marijuana legal for adults was approved in California
column3: opening the most populous U.S. state to a burgeoning commercial cannabis market in a major victory for supporters of liberalized drug laws.Proposition 64 passed easily as statewide returns from the election showed nearly 56 percent of voters favoring the measure and 44 percent opposed
column4: according to results on Wednesday morning reported from more than 90 percent of precincts.California was by far the largest of five states with ballot measures seeking to legalize the use of marijuana for the sheer pleasure of its intoxicating effects
column5: and approval there extends legalization to the entire U.S. Pacific Coast.Recreational marijuana was first approved in 2012 by Washington state and Colorado
column6: and later by voters in Oregon
column7: Alaska and the District of Columbia.Victory also was declared on Tuesday by supporters of a similar measure in Massachusetts
column8: giving legalized recreational pot its first toehold in New England. Nevada voters also backed legalization for recreational purposes
column9: but neighboring Arizona rejected a similar proposal. In the fifth state
column11: the result was too close to call on Wednesday morning.The Marijuana Policy Project
column12: the nation's leading organization supporting liberalization of cannabis laws
column13: likewise projected passage of measures permitting medical use of marijuana in Florida
column16: 25 states had already legalized cannabis in some way
column17: whether for medical or recreational uses

column1: Approval in California alone
column2: home to 39 million people
column3: means that almost a fifth of all Americans live in states where recreational marijuana is legal
column4: according to U.S. Census figures. California was the first U.S. state to legalize medical marijuana
column5: doing so in 1996. 'BEING LIKE BEER'

column1: The new measure
column2: spearheaded by a coalition of supporters that included Democratic Lieutenant Governor Gavin Newsom and billionaire high-tech entrepreneur Sean Parker
column3: allows adults to possess and use up to an ounce of pot for private
column4: recreational use. It also permits personal cultivation of as many as six cannabis plants. Moreover
column5: it would establish a system to license
column6: regulate and tax sales of marijuana
column7: while allowing city governments to exercise local control over commercial distribution within their borders.California voters defeated a similar initiative in 2010
column8: but public opinion polls show attitudes have since shifted.Opponents of liberalized marijuana laws have argued that such measures carry major public safety risks and would make pot more accessible to youngsters.

column1: Experts say the latest initiatives include more sophisticated regulatory mechanisms aimed at keeping cannabis away from children and banning the involvement of criminal gangs and drug cartels.They also point to the potential for hundreds of millions in additional state tax revenue from pot sales and billions in economic activity. Investors new to the sector said they are eager for a piece of a recreational marijuana market that by some estimates will reach $50 billion over the next decade.""It's changed in the minds of these voters from being like cocaine to being like beer
column2: said University of Southern California political scientist John Matsusaka.Civil rights groups have also embraced legalization
column3: arguing that current marijuana laws have led to a disproportionate number of minorities being incarcerated for minor drug offenses. (Additional reporting by Steve Gorman in Los Angeles; Editing by Peter Cooney and Mary Milliken)"	[]	[]
